title: What can we learn from medieval history? - Quora

response.answer_text: the most interesting question here. Do read the importance of the XII and the XIII centuries, considered as the first Renaissance and the first industrial, scientific and political revolution. There are so many things to be learned. Unfortunately, most modern historians have ignored the essential facts, promoting only the “ ignorance, violence, bigotry” of common people. The nobility has been described since 1789 as the worst category of people that ever lived. Thanks to Wikipedia and sites like this one, the people of today can find the importance of the personalities in that epoch for the following ones and for today. The XIII century was the time of the first institutions that are now ruling Europe, based on representative government. Emperor Frederick II de Hohenstaufen created the Constitution of Melfi, an attempt to set the rules for what was the nearest organization of what is now the EU. Simon de Montfort, Earl of Leicester, husband of princess Eleanor Plantagenet and Frederick’s brother in law , summoned the first assembly showing the main traits of the House of Commons, the mother of all Parliaments of today.
